issue.title: Babysitting long-running Copr builds (triggered by build, not periodic)
issue.body:
Sentry Issue: [PCKT-002-PACKIT-SERVICE-4Q2](https://sentry.io/organizations/red-hat-it/issues/3600503723/?referrer=github_integration)

```
PackitCoprBuildTimeoutException: No feedback for copr build id=5101070 yet
  File "celery/app/trace.py", line 734, in __protected_call__
    return self.run(*args, **kwargs)
  File "celery/app/autoretry.py", line 54, in run
    ret = task.retry(exc=exc, **retry_kwargs)
  File "celery/app/task.py", line 717, in retry
    raise_with_context(exc)
  File "celery/app/autoretry.py", line 34, in run
    return task._orig_run(*args, **kwargs)
  File "packit_service/worker/tasks.py", line 135, in babysit_copr_build
    raise PackitCoprBuildTimeoutException(
```

When running Copr builds for long time, e.g. in this case we are talking about `systemd` or `osbuild-composer` and 8+ hours (max seems to be 10), the default babysitting job raises an exception after it uses all of the retries (which should be retried in the **best-case** scenario after 8 hours).

Do we actually **need** to track those failures when we have periodic babysitting run?

issue.title: GitHub installation API rate limit can be exceeded
issue.body:
Sentry Issue: [PCKT-002-PACKIT-SERVICE-4W9](https://sentry.io/organizations/red-hat-it/issues/3741986814/?referrer=github_integration)

```
RateLimitExceededException: 403 {"message": "API rate limit exceeded for installation ID 23294320.", "documentation_url": "https://docs.github.com/rest/overview/resources-in-the-rest-api#rate-limiting"}
  File "ogr/services/github/project.py", line 428, in get_file_content
    return self.github_repo.get_contents(
  File "ogr/services/github/project.py", line 82, in github_repo
    self._github_repo = self.github_instance.get_repo(
  File "github/MainClass.py", line 330, in get_repo
    headers, data = self.__requester.requestJsonAndCheck("GET", url)
  File "github/Requester.py", line 353, in requestJsonAndCheck
    return self.__check(
  File "github/Requester.py", line 378, in __check
    raise self.__createException(status, responseHeaders, output)

GithubAPIException: 
(5 additional frame(s) were not displayed)
...
  File "packit/config/package_config.py", line 244, in get_package_config_from_repo
    config_file_content = project.get_file_content(
  File "ogr/abstract.py", line 118, in wrapper
    __check_for_internal_failure(ex)
  File "ogr/abstract.py", line 60, in __check_for_internal_failure
    raise ex
  File "ogr/abstract.py", line 108, in wrapper
    return function(*args, **kwargs)
  File "ogr/services/github/project.py", line 434, in get_file_content
    raise GithubAPIException() from ex
```

Here are the docs dor the API rate limits: https://docs.github.com/en/developers/apps/building-github-apps/rate-limits-for-github-apps#default-server-to-server-rate-limits-for-githubcom

Let's investigate what we can do here. Here are a few ideas:
* We can try regenerating the per-installation-token if it helps.
* When we hit this, we can wait (return the task to the queue).
* It would be nice to know about this in advance. Check if there is a way to get the current state of the limit.

----

*issue author: @lachmanfrantisek*

issue.title: Cannot import ProFormA task with "Makefile"
issue.body:
A ProFormA task created in CodeHarbor with a Makefile cannot be imported (or rather displayed) correctly in CodeOcean.

I already identified the cause:

https://github.com/openHPI/codeocean/blob/574e99eddd284cba9df3075c5c32fa311c923964/app/services/proforma_service/convert_task_to_exercise.rb#L84-L101

Here, we get the `extname` of the file:

https://github.com/openHPI/codeocean/blob/574e99eddd284cba9df3075c5c32fa311c923964/app/services/proforma_service/convert_task_to_exercise.rb#L85

For a `Makefile`, however, this is empty:

```rb
File.extname("Makefile")
 => "" 
```

Therefore, the Makefile (which is also a file type in CodeOcean) is not attached.

Closes CODEOCEAN-G3

issue.title: Twin:te にインポートで `year` パラメータが要求されている
issue.body:
## 問題

現在の Twin:te Front の実装では、インポートのクエリに `year` を要求しているように思える。（[該当コード](https://github.com/twin-te/twinte-front/blob/5e5877b533ffac1f3f6d2d1d976463adafe75cd7/src/ui/pages/import.vue#L119)）

しかし[開発者向けドキュメント](https://github.com/twin-te/twinte-landing-page/tree/main/docs)ではインポート時に年度は意図的に指定できないようになっているように思える。

これにより、[KdBもどき](https://make-it-tsukuba.github.io/alternative-tsukuba-kdb/)が発行する Twin:te にインポート URL が無効化されているように思える。

KdB もどきが発行する URL の例）
`https://make-it-tsukuba.github.io/alternative-tsukuba-kdb/`

issue.title: panic: thread 'coordinator' panicked at 'Dataflow temp-view-t251 requested `as_of`
issue.body:
### What version of Materialize are you using?

v0.33.3 (2982e6bca)

### How did you install Materialize?

Materialize Cloud

### What is the issue?

Environmentd panics and crashes if you try to select from two different schemas in the same transactions, repro steps:

```sql
materialize=> create table t1 (f1 int);
CREATE TABLE
materialize=> insert into t1 values (1);
INSERT 0 1

materialize=> begin;
BEGIN
materialize=*> select * from t1;
 f1 
----
  1
(1 row)

materialize=*> select * from mz_views;
SSL SYSCALL error: EOF detected
The connection to the server was lost. Attempting reset: Failed.
The connection to the server was lost. Attempting reset: Failed.
!?>

The reindex user operation cannot be run in production due to users count

issue.title: Avro schema generation can create an invalid schema

labels.name: A-ADAPTER
labels.description: Topics related to the ADAPTER layer

issue.body:
### What version of Materialize are you using?

v0.32.3

### How did you install Materialize?

Materialize Cloud

### What is the issue?

In the log lines below, `<name>` starts with a number, which points to a `CREATE SINK` that spits out a warning, then crashes envd. Validation here should not crash, and we should not make it to avro parsing before spitting out an error to user about naming requirements.

### Relevant log output

```source
2022-11-29T15:30:59.756466Z  WARN mz_sql::plan::statement::ddl: Verification of upsert key disabled for sink '<sink_name>' via 'NOT ENFORCED'. This is potentially dangerous and can lead to crashing materialize when the specified key is not in fact a unique key of the sinked view.
thread 'coordinator' panicked at 'valid schema constructed: ParseSchema(ParseSchemaError("Invalid name. Must start with [A-Za-z_] and subsequently only contain [A-Za-z0-9_]. Found: <name>"))', src/interchange/src/avro/encode.rs:138:56
```

issue.title: yanks might get ignored when the build is still queued

labels.name: E-easy
labels.description: Effort: Should be easy to implement and would make a good first PR

labels.name: A-builds
labels.description: Area: Building the documentation for a crate

issue.body:
So it's not forgotten I'll write down my findings here. 

When we get a `Yank` change from crates-index-diff, we are running an `UPDATE` statement on the `releases` table. 

We only add the release to that table after the build is finished, so when the release is still in our build-queue, or in progress, the yank wouldn't do anything. 

Since we don't check the number of updated rows for that `UPDATE` statement, this also never lead to an error. 


While we could solve this issue by storing the yank-state in the build-queue too, this could also be solved via solving #1011.

issue.title: persist: investigate adding an idempotency token to compare_and_append
issue.body:
The return type of `WriteHandle::compare_and_append` is `-> Result<Result<Result<(), Upper<T>>, InvalidUsage<T>>, ExternalError>`. Notably, after, initializing a shard in the first place, this is the only method in persist that forwards on an ExternalError for the persist user to deal with. Petros wonders whether we can do anything about this.

First, the reason it's there in the first place. The ExternalError in question represents an _indeterminate_ (also commonly called indefinite) error from persist's interaction with aurora. This class of error means that the operation _may have_ been successful but also _may not have_. There are other external systems involved in a compare_and_append call (notably s3) but persist already indefinitely retries these. It also already retries _determinate_ (also called definite) errors on the aurora call.

The compare_and_append signature is currently what it is because of experience with the edge cases involved from maelstrom testing. Specifically, persist's maelstrom testing models a transactional kv api, but it's a close analog for how SQL txns will work at the Materialize level. A transaction is executed as follows:

- the reads are evaluated at `read_ts`
- the writes are staged into a set of differential KVTD tuples at time `write_ts=read_ts+1`
- this batch of tuples is handed to persist `compare_and_append` with `expected_upper=[write_ts]` and `new_upper=[write_ts+1]`. if another txn has concurrently committed, then the compare_and_append call will fail with an expected upper mismatch, and the loop is run again at the new `read_ts`
- more details available at https://github.com/MaterializeInc/materialize/blob/a8c7d5a0e7c2938ce4008cf05618494a82f7a48a/src/persist-client/examples/maelstrom/txn.rs#L53-L96

If we retryied this indeterminate error, the issue that comes up is if on retry we find out that we have an expected upper mismatch. The question is whether the upper is different because our previous errored attempt _actually succeeded_ or if it's different because we raced with another txn and they won. If we retry the first, we'll double commit the txn, which is a correctness violation.

In the case of a SQL txn that we are evaluating on behalf of a user, we can return forward the indeterminate error to them as a pgwire error code that itself indicates an indeterminate error. This is something that is unavoidable in truly distributed SQL database (e.g CockroachDB) for similar reasons to what's described above.

Sources, on the other hand, have more information and, with care, can avoid either bubbling up the error or panic-ing. This breaks down to roughly two cases:

- timestamp bindings: The compare_and_append on behalf of timestamp bindings is free to retry the ExternalError. If it then hits an expected upper mis-match, it can proceed the same way regardless of whether it's "racing with itself" or actually racing with another timestamp binding process. Reload the state from scratch as if starting for the first time (more likely have a permanent Listen and wait for it to update) and rerun the timestamp binding logic.
- raw reclocked source data: Similar to the above, if a compare_and_append fails, load the new timestamp bindings and rerun the reclocking logic.

Petros's (very much reasonable) request is for persist to internally use an idempotency token to reduce/remove storage's need to reason about this in the first place. The question of whether this is possible at all is clearly yes. However, to me, the real question is where along the spectrum of things we can do is the right place to be.

On one end, we have the current situation of no idempotency token and no internal retries of indeterminate errors on the aurora cas operation.

On the other end, we remove the ExternalError from the signature entirely and figure out how to make that correct for all of sql txns, timestamp bindings, and raw reclocked source data. The trivial way to do this (tho unworkable for obvious reasons) is to generate a unique idempotency token for every write and whenever a write commits to the persist state, it atomically adds its token to an uncompactable list in the state. This would allow persist to always be able to distinguish between the "raced with self" vs "raced with other" case.

But can we do this without the (unworkable) unbounded state? I'm about 90% sure the answer is no for reasons I'll explain below. However, I do feel there's _something_ in this spectrum that we could make work for everyone. I'm just not sure what it is yet and AFAICT, at earliest, we don't need to figure this out until some part of M2. At which point, we'll have more time (ha) and more experience with the subtleties of all this stuff.

Okay, here's why the general problem is hard. Given the following assumptions:
- We must always be correct
- Persist compare_and_append calls must be "cancel safe". (This is the only sort of timeout available in persist and I'm not ready to make this sort of opinionated change without getting more experience running this stuff in prod than we have right now.)
- The standard distributed systems assumptions (networks are fallible, reorderings can happen, etc)

If we aim to get rid of ExternalError entirely, this means each individual compare_and_append call must be able to (a) get an Indeterminate error and then (b) get an upper mismatch on retry and (c) _always_ be able to correctly determine whether that individual write applied or not. At long last, the reasons this is hard (not possible?) with bounded state is the following:

- We can't distinguish between metadata (unique id per write handle, expected_upper, new_upper etc) because it's always possible that a previous write_and_append call with exactly the same metadata got sent off from the same WriteHandle, timed out and returned control to the persist user after sending off the aurora cas call, and then the aurora cas hung out in the network until hitting aurora at just the wrong moment. It matters if it was the earlier call vs this one because they could have different data/updates, which are stored in s3.
- Okay so can we look up the data in s3 and then tell for sure? Not always. While all these retries were happening, it's possible that some ReadHandle advanced the since and then compaction has erased the ability to distinguish updates at the original timestamps.

Here's some unstructured thoughts from the last time I had this loaded up in my head:
- A trivial thing is to give each write a unique idempotency token and store in the persist state the token of the _most recent_ write. A variant of this is to store the token of the _most recent write for each write handle_. These would cover the vast vast majority of cases in practice, but doesn't allow us to remove ExternalError from the signature entirely.
- Add an explicit timeout to compare_and_append (including a new error type in the return) and then say compare_and_append is not cancel safe. Users that know they aren't handing in a timeout could safely panic on it. This is real clunky.
- A possibly workable option is for a timeout (dropped compare_and_set future) to "posion" the current writer_id locally on the WriteHandle. Perhaps by setting a bool or something at the start of the write and unsetting it when the aurora cas is resolved. Then if another compare_and_set comes and the bool is poisoned, it first expires the old writer id (to keep bounded state size), registers a new writer id (which doesn't necessarily need to involve the network), and then proceed as normal. This would maybe allow persist to use some combination of writer_id, write_idempotency_token, new_upper to always be able to distinguish the two cases? It would also have the benefit of "pay for what you use" in that persist users that don't timeout never hit this extra logic. It's not _obviously_ correct to me exactly how this would work and it's also quite a subtle/brittle protocol involving persist state, local write handle state, and some knowledge of orderings, so I'd be pretty anxious about moving to this without some really solid adversarial testing to make sure it doesn't break end-to-end.

issue.title: fix(developer): handle shutdown cleanup more cleanly
issue.body:
Fixes #4757.
Fixes #6928.

This may also fix some other Developer crashes relating to CEF, as some of those are probably due to unclean shutdown.

Three separate ways shutdown is more robust:

1. Destroy main form before web server -- this ensures that all main form routines have deregistered app sources from web server.
2. In some situations, `FormClose` can be skipped by shutdown routines, for example, if you call `Application.Terminate`. This change ensures that we get a second chance to cleanup in the form destructor with `DoCloseCleanup`.
3. In the Online Update Check, instead of `Application.Terminate`, we now use `Application.MainForm.Close`, which is much more polite, as it ensures that changed files are saved, etc, and does proper cleanup. This particular change may make the other two somewhat irrelevant but they are still sensible as they will cover us for other potential form destruction sequences.

@keymanapp-test-bot skip

Note: when the regression test for Keyman Developer is run for Beta, we'll be checking most of these code pathways. Some of these are hard to reproduce in beta testing in any case, so we'll monitor Sentry for other possible crash reports.

issue.title: Babysitting long-running Copr builds (triggered by build, not periodic)
issue.body:
Sentry Issue: [PCKT-002-PACKIT-SERVICE-4Q2](https://sentry.io/organizations/red-hat-it/issues/3600503723/?referrer=github_integration)

```
PackitCoprBuildTimeoutException: No feedback for copr build id=5101070 yet
  File "celery/app/trace.py", line 734, in __protected_call__
    return self.run(*args, **kwargs)
  File "celery/app/autoretry.py", line 54, in run
    ret = task.retry(exc=exc, **retry_kwargs)
  File "celery/app/task.py", line 717, in retry
    raise_with_context(exc)
  File "celery/app/autoretry.py", line 34, in run
    return task._orig_run(*args, **kwargs)
  File "packit_service/worker/tasks.py", line 135, in babysit_copr_build
    raise PackitCoprBuildTimeoutException(
```

When running Copr builds for long time, e.g. in this case we are talking about `systemd` or `osbuild-composer` and 8+ hours (max seems to be 10), the default babysitting job raises an exception after it uses all of the retries (which should be retried in the **best-case** scenario after 8 hours).

Do we actually **need** to track those failures when we have periodic babysitting run?

issue.title: GitHub installation API rate limit can be exceeded
issue.body:
Sentry Issue: [PCKT-002-PACKIT-SERVICE-4W9](https://sentry.io/organizations/red-hat-it/issues/3741986814/?referrer=github_integration)

```
RateLimitExceededException: 403 {"message": "API rate limit exceeded for installation ID 23294320.", "documentation_url": "https://docs.github.com/rest/overview/resources-in-the-rest-api#rate-limiting"}
  File "ogr/services/github/project.py", line 428, in get_file_content
    return self.github_repo.get_contents(
  File "ogr/services/github/project.py", line 82, in github_repo
    self._github_repo = self.github_instance.get_repo(
  File "github/MainClass.py", line 330, in get_repo
    headers, data = self.__requester.requestJsonAndCheck("GET", url)
  File "github/Requester.py", line 353, in requestJsonAndCheck
    return self.__check(
  File "github/Requester.py", line 378, in __check
    raise self.__createException(status, responseHeaders, output)

GithubAPIException: 
(5 additional frame(s) were not displayed)
...
  File "packit/config/package_config.py", line 244, in get_package_config_from_repo
    config_file_content = project.get_file_content(
  File "ogr/abstract.py", line 118, in wrapper
    __check_for_internal_failure(ex)
  File "ogr/abstract.py", line 60, in __check_for_internal_failure
    raise ex
  File "ogr/abstract.py", line 108, in wrapper
    return function(*args, **kwargs)
  File "ogr/services/github/project.py", line 434, in get_file_content
    raise GithubAPIException() from ex
```

Here are the docs dor the API rate limits: https://docs.github.com/en/developers/apps/building-github-apps/rate-limits-for-github-apps#default-server-to-server-rate-limits-for-githubcom

Let's investigate what we can do here. Here are a few ideas:
* We can try regenerating the per-installation-token if it helps.
* When we hit this, we can wait (return the task to the queue).
* It would be nice to know about this in advance. Check if there is a way to get the current state of the limit.

----

*issue author: @lachmanfrantisek*

issue.title: Cannot import ProFormA task with "Makefile"
issue.body:
A ProFormA task created in CodeHarbor with a Makefile cannot be imported (or rather displayed) correctly in CodeOcean.

I already identified the cause:

https://github.com/openHPI/codeocean/blob/574e99eddd284cba9df3075c5c32fa311c923964/app/services/proforma_service/convert_task_to_exercise.rb#L84-L101

Here, we get the `extname` of the file:

https://github.com/openHPI/codeocean/blob/574e99eddd284cba9df3075c5c32fa311c923964/app/services/proforma_service/convert_task_to_exercise.rb#L85

For a `Makefile`, however, this is empty:

```rb
File.extname("Makefile")
 => "" 
```

Therefore, the Makefile (which is also a file type in CodeOcean) is not attached.

Closes CODEOCEAN-G3

issue.title: Twin:te にインポートで `year` パラメータが要求されている
issue.body:
## 問題

現在の Twin:te Front の実装では、インポートのクエリに `year` を要求しているように思える。（[該当コード](https://github.com/twin-te/twinte-front/blob/5e5877b533ffac1f3f6d2d1d976463adafe75cd7/src/ui/pages/import.vue#L119)）

しかし[開発者向けドキュメント](https://github.com/twin-te/twinte-landing-page/tree/main/docs)ではインポート時に年度は意図的に指定できないようになっているように思える。

これにより、[KdBもどき](https://make-it-tsukuba.github.io/alternative-tsukuba-kdb/)が発行する Twin:te にインポート URL が無効化されているように思える。

KdB もどきが発行する URL の例）
`https://make-it-tsukuba.github.io/alternative-tsukuba-kdb/`

issue.title: panic: thread 'coordinator' panicked at 'Dataflow temp-view-t251 requested `as_of`
issue.body:
### What version of Materialize are you using?

v0.33.3 (2982e6bca)

### How did you install Materialize?

Materialize Cloud

### What is the issue?

Environmentd panics and crashes if you try to select from two different schemas in the same transactions, repro steps:

```sql
materialize=> create table t1 (f1 int);
CREATE TABLE
materialize=> insert into t1 values (1);
INSERT 0 1

materialize=> begin;
BEGIN
materialize=*> select * from t1;
 f1 
----
  1
(1 row)

materialize=*> select * from mz_views;
SSL SYSCALL error: EOF detected
The connection to the server was lost. Attempting reset: Failed.
The connection to the server was lost. Attempting reset: Failed.
!?> 
```

issue.title: fix: operations reindex users reach max meilisearch connection

labels.name: state/triage 🚦
labels.description: Has not been triaged & therefore, not ready for work

issue.body:
### Describe the bug

The reindex user operation cannot be run in production due to users count

### To Reproduce

1. Add more than 1000 users to your database
2. Launch `stud42cli operations reindexusers`

### Expected behavior

_No response_

### Relevant log output

```Shell
11:47PM INF Start the re-indexation of the users version=v0.19
11:47PM INF Start the re-indexation of the users batchCount=27 usersCount=26714 version=v0.19
11:47PM INF Reindexing users in batch batchId=0 usersCount=1000 version=v0.19
11:47PM FTL failed to index user error="MeilisearchCommunicationError unable to execute request (path \"PUT /indexes/s42_users/documents?primaryKey=id\" with method \"UpdateDocuments\"): no free connections available to host" version=v0.19
```


### Version of software

0.19

### Environment

Live (https://s42.app)

### Additional context

_No response_

issue.title: Avro schema generation can create an invalid schema

labels.name: A-ADAPTER
labels.description: Topics related to the ADAPTER layer

issue.body:
### What version of Materialize are you using?

v0.32.3

### How did you install Materialize?

Materialize Cloud

### What is the issue?

In the log lines below, `<name>` starts with a number, which points to a `CREATE SINK` that spits out a warning, then crashes envd. Validation here should not crash, and we should not make it to avro parsing before spitting out an error to user about naming requirements.

### Relevant log output

```source
2022-11-29T15:30:59.756466Z  WARN mz_sql::plan::statement::ddl: Verification of upsert key disabled for sink '<sink_name>' via 'NOT ENFORCED'. This is potentially dangerous and can lead to crashing materialize when the specified key is not in fact a unique key of the sinked view.
thread 'coordinator' panicked at 'valid schema constructed: ParseSchema(ParseSchemaError("Invalid name. Must start with [A-Za-z_] and subsequently only contain [A-Za-z0-9_]. Found: <name>"))', src/interchange/src/avro/encode.rs:138:56
```

issue.title: 'Request aborted' error sent to Sentry

issue.title: yanks might get ignored when the build is still queued

labels.name: E-easy
labels.description: Effort: Should be easy to implement and would make a good first PR

labels.name: A-builds
labels.description: Area: Building the documentation for a crate

issue.body:
So it's not forgotten I'll write down my findings here. 

When we get a `Yank` change from crates-index-diff, we are running an `UPDATE` statement on the `releases` table. 

We only add the release to that table after the build is finished, so when the release is still in our build-queue, or in progress, the yank wouldn't do anything. 

Since we don't check the number of updated rows for that `UPDATE` statement, this also never lead to an error. 


While we could solve this issue by storing the yank-state in the build-queue too, this could also be solved via solving #1011.

issue.title: persist: investigate adding an idempotency token to compare_and_append
issue.body:
The return type of `WriteHandle::compare_and_append` is `-> Result<Result<Result<(), Upper<T>>, InvalidUsage<T>>, ExternalError>`. Notably, after, initializing a shard in the first place, this is the only method in persist that forwards on an ExternalError for the persist user to deal with. Petros wonders whether we can do anything about this.

First, the reason it's there in the first place. The ExternalError in question represents an _indeterminate_ (also commonly called indefinite) error from persist's interaction with aurora. This class of error means that the operation _may have_ been successful but also _may not have_. There are other external systems involved in a compare_and_append call (notably s3) but persist already indefinitely retries these. It also already retries _determinate_ (also called definite) errors on the aurora call.

The compare_and_append signature is currently what it is because of experience with the edge cases involved from maelstrom testing. Specifically, persist's maelstrom testing models a transactional kv api, but it's a close analog for how SQL txns will work at the Materialize level. A transaction is executed as follows:

- the reads are evaluated at `read_ts`
- the writes are staged into a set of differential KVTD tuples at time `write_ts=read_ts+1`
- this batch of tuples is handed to persist `compare_and_append` with `expected_upper=[write_ts]` and `new_upper=[write_ts+1]`. if another txn has concurrently committed, then the compare_and_append call will fail with an expected upper mismatch, and the loop is run again at the new `read_ts`
- more details available at https://github.com/MaterializeInc/materialize/blob/a8c7d5a0e7c2938ce4008cf05618494a82f7a48a/src/persist-client/examples/maelstrom/txn.rs#L53-L96

If we retryied this indeterminate error, the issue that comes up is if on retry we find out that we have an expected upper mismatch. The question is whether the upper is different because our previous errored attempt _actually succeeded_ or if it's different because we raced with another txn and they won. If we retry the first, we'll double commit the txn, which is a correctness violation.

In the case of a SQL txn that we are evaluating on behalf of a user, we can return forward the indeterminate error to them as a pgwire error code that itself indicates an indeterminate error. This is something that is unavoidable in truly distributed SQL database (e.g CockroachDB) for similar reasons to what's described above.

Sources, on the other hand, have more information and, with care, can avoid either bubbling up the error or panic-ing. This breaks down to roughly two cases:

- timestamp bindings: The compare_and_append on behalf of timestamp bindings is free to retry the ExternalError. If it then hits an expected upper mis-match, it can proceed the same way regardless of whether it's "racing with itself" or actually racing with another timestamp binding process. Reload the state from scratch as if starting for the first time (more likely have a permanent Listen and wait for it to update) and rerun the timestamp binding logic.
- raw reclocked source data: Similar to the above, if a compare_and_append fails, load the new timestamp bindings and rerun the reclocking logic.

Petros's (very much reasonable) request is for persist to internally use an idempotency token to reduce/remove storage's need to reason about this in the first place. The question of whether this is possible at all is clearly yes. However, to me, the real question is where along the spectrum of things we can do is the right place to be.

On one end, we have the current situation of no idempotency token and no internal retries of indeterminate errors on the aurora cas operation.

On the other end, we remove the ExternalError from the signature entirely and figure out how to make that correct for all of sql txns, timestamp bindings, and raw reclocked source data. The trivial way to do this (tho unworkable for obvious reasons) is to generate a unique idempotency token for every write and whenever a write commits to the persist state, it atomically adds its token to an uncompactable list in the state. This would allow persist to always be able to distinguish between the "raced with self" vs "raced with other" case.

But can we do this without the (unworkable) unbounded state? I'm about 90% sure the answer is no for reasons I'll explain below. However, I do feel there's _something_ in this spectrum that we could make work for everyone. I'm just not sure what it is yet and AFAICT, at earliest, we don't need to figure this out until some part of M2. At which point, we'll have more time (ha) and more experience with the subtleties of all this stuff.

Okay, here's why the general problem is hard. Given the following assumptions:
- We must always be correct
- Persist compare_and_append calls must be "cancel safe". (This is the only sort of timeout available in persist and I'm not ready to make this sort of opinionated change without getting more experience running this stuff in prod than we have right now.)
- The standard distributed systems assumptions (networks are fallible, reorderings can happen, etc)

If we aim to get rid of ExternalError entirely, this means each individual compare_and_append call must be able to (a) get an Indeterminate error and then (b) get an upper mismatch on retry and (c) _always_ be able to correctly determine whether that individual write applied or not. At long last, the reasons this is hard (not possible?) with bounded state is the following:

- We can't distinguish between metadata (unique id per write handle, expected_upper, new_upper etc) because it's always possible that a previous write_and_append call with exactly the same metadata got sent off from the same WriteHandle, timed out and returned control to the persist user after sending off the aurora cas call, and then the aurora cas hung out in the network until hitting aurora at just the wrong moment. It matters if it was the earlier call vs this one because they could have different data/updates, which are stored in s3.
- Okay so can we look up the data in s3 and then tell for sure? Not always. While all these retries were happening, it's possible that some ReadHandle advanced the since and then compaction has erased the ability to distinguish updates at the original timestamps.

Here's some unstructured thoughts from the last time I had this loaded up in my head:
- A trivial thing is to give each write a unique idempotency token and store in the persist state the token of the _most recent_ write. A variant of this is to store the token of the _most recent write for each write handle_. These would cover the vast vast majority of cases in practice, but doesn't allow us to remove ExternalError from the signature entirely.
- Add an explicit timeout to compare_and_append (including a new error type in the return) and then say compare_and_append is not cancel safe. Users that know they aren't handing in a timeout could safely panic on it. This is real clunky.
- A possibly workable option is for a timeout (dropped compare_and_set future) to "posion" the current writer_id locally on the WriteHandle. Perhaps by setting a bool or something at the start of the write and unsetting it when the aurora cas is resolved. Then if another compare_and_set comes and the bool is poisoned, it first expires the old writer id (to keep bounded state size), registers a new writer id (which doesn't necessarily need to involve the network), and then proceed as normal. This would maybe allow persist to use some combination of writer_id, write_idempotency_token, new_upper to always be able to distinguish the two cases? It would also have the benefit of "pay for what you use" in that persist users that don't timeout never hit this extra logic. It's not _obviously_ correct to me exactly how this would work and it's also quite a subtle/brittle protocol involving persist state, local write handle state, and some knowledge of orderings, so I'd be pretty anxious about moving to this without some really solid adversarial testing to make sure it doesn't break end-to-end.

issue.title: fix(developer): handle shutdown cleanup more cleanly
issue.body:
Fixes #4757.
Fixes #6928.

This may also fix some other Developer crashes relating to CEF, as some of those are probably due to unclean shutdown.

Three separate ways shutdown is more robust:

1. Destroy main form before web server -- this ensures that all main form routines have deregistered app sources from web server.
2. In some situations, `FormClose` can be skipped by shutdown routines, for example, if you call `Application.Terminate`. This change ensures that we get a second chance to cleanup in the form destructor with `DoCloseCleanup`.
3. In the Online Update Check, instead of `Application.Terminate`, we now use `Application.MainForm.Close`, which is much more polite, as it ensures that changed files are saved, etc, and does proper cleanup. This particular change may make the other two somewhat irrelevant but they are still sensible as they will cover us for other potential form destruction sequences.

@keymanapp-test-bot skip

Note: when the regression test for Keyman Developer is run for Beta, we'll be checking most of these code pathways. Some of these are hard to reproduce in beta testing in any case, so we'll monitor Sentry for other possible crash reports.

issue.title: Babysitting long-running Copr builds (triggered by build, not periodic)
issue.body:
Sentry Issue: [PCKT-002-PACKIT-SERVICE-4Q2](https://sentry.io/organizations/red-hat-it/issues/3600503723/?referrer=github_integration)

```
PackitCoprBuildTimeoutException: No feedback for copr build id=5101070 yet
  File "celery/app/trace.py", line 734, in __protected_call__
    return self.run(*args, **kwargs)
  File "celery/app/autoretry.py", line 54, in run
    ret = task.retry(exc=exc, **retry_kwargs)
  File "celery/app/task.py", line 717, in retry
    raise_with_context(exc)
  File "celery/app/autoretry.py", line 34, in run
    return task._orig_run(*args, **kwargs)
  File "packit_service/worker/tasks.py", line 135, in babysit_copr_build
    raise PackitCoprBuildTimeoutException(
```

When running Copr builds for long time, e.g. in this case we are talking about `systemd` or `osbuild-composer` and 8+ hours (max seems to be 10), the default babysitting job raises an exception after it uses all of the retries (which should be retried in the **best-case** scenario after 8 hours).

Do we actually **need** to track those failures when we have periodic babysitting run?

issue.title: GitHub installation API rate limit can be exceeded
issue.body:
Sentry Issue: [PCKT-002-PACKIT-SERVICE-4W9](https://sentry.io/organizations/red-hat-it/issues/3741986814/?referrer=github_integration)

```
RateLimitExceededException: 403 {"message": "API rate limit exceeded for installation ID 23294320.", "documentation_url": "https://docs.github.com/rest/overview/resources-in-the-rest-api#rate-limiting"}
  File "ogr/services/github/project.py", line 428, in get_file_content
    return self.github_repo.get_contents(
  File "ogr/services/github/project.py", line 82, in github_repo
    self._github_repo = self.github_instance.get_repo(
  File "github/MainClass.py", line 330, in get_repo
    headers, data = self.__requester.requestJsonAndCheck("GET", url)
  File "github/Requester.py", line 353, in requestJsonAndCheck
    return self.__check(
  File "github/Requester.py", line 378, in __check
    raise self.__createException(status, responseHeaders, output)

GithubAPIException: 
(5 additional frame(s) were not displayed)
...
  File "packit/config/package_config.py", line 244, in get_package_config_from_repo
    config_file_content = project.get_file_content(
  File "ogr/abstract.py", line 118, in wrapper
    __check_for_internal_failure(ex)
  File "ogr/abstract.py", line 60, in __check_for_internal_failure
    raise ex
  File "ogr/abstract.py", line 108, in wrapper
    return function(*args, **kwargs)
  File "ogr/services/github/project.py", line 434, in get_file_content
    raise GithubAPIException() from ex
```

Here are the docs dor the API rate limits: https://docs.github.com/en/developers/apps/building-github-apps/rate-limits-for-github-apps#default-server-to-server-rate-limits-for-githubcom

Let's investigate what we can do here. Here are a few ideas:
* We can try regenerating the per-installation-token if it helps.
* When we hit this, we can wait (return the task to the queue).
* It would be nice to know about this in advance. Check if there is a way to get the current state of the limit.

----

*issue author: @lachmanfrantisek*

issue.title: Cannot import ProFormA task with "Makefile"
issue.body:
A ProFormA task created in CodeHarbor with a Makefile cannot be imported (or rather displayed) correctly in CodeOcean.

I already identified the cause:

https://github.com/openHPI/codeocean/blob/574e99eddd284cba9df3075c5c32fa311c923964/app/services/proforma_service/convert_task_to_exercise.rb#L84-L101

Here, we get the `extname` of the file:

https://github.com/openHPI/codeocean/blob/574e99eddd284cba9df3075c5c32fa311c923964/app/services/proforma_service/convert_task_to_exercise.rb#L85

For a `Makefile`, however, this is empty:

```rb
File.extname("Makefile")
 => "" 
```

Therefore, the Makefile (which is also a file type in CodeOcean) is not attached.

Closes CODEOCEAN-G3

issue.title: Twin:te にインポートで `year` パラメータが要求されている
issue.body:
## 問題

現在の Twin:te Front の実装では、インポートのクエリに `year` を要求しているように思える。（[該当コード](https://github.com/twin-te/twinte-front/blob/5e5877b533ffac1f3f6d2d1d976463adafe75cd7/src/ui/pages/import.vue#L119)）

しかし[開発者向けドキュメント](https://github.com/twin-te/twinte-landing-page/tree/main/docs)ではインポート時に年度は意図的に指定できないようになっているように思える。

これにより、[KdBもどき](https://make-it-tsukuba.github.io/alternative-tsukuba-kdb/)が発行する Twin:te にインポート URL が無効化されているように思える。

KdB もどきが発行する URL の例）
`https://make-it-tsukuba.github.io/alternative-tsukuba-kdb/`

issue.title: panic: thread 'coordinator' panicked at 'Dataflow temp-view-t251 requested `as_of`
issue.body:
### What version of Materialize are you using?

v0.33.3 (2982e6bca)

### How did you install Materialize?

Materialize Cloud

### What is the issue?

Environmentd panics and crashes if you try to select from two different schemas in the same transactions, repro steps:

```sql
materialize=> create table t1 (f1 int);
CREATE TABLE
materialize=> insert into t1 values (1);
INSERT 0 1

materialize=> begin;
BEGIN
materialize=*> select * from t1;
 f1 
----
  1
(1 row)

materialize=*> select * from mz_views;
SSL SYSCALL error: EOF detected
The connection to the server was lost. Attempting reset: Failed.
The connection to the server was lost. Attempting reset: Failed.
!?> 
```

issue.title: fix: operations reindex users reach max meilisearch connection

labels.name: state/triage 🚦
labels.description: Has not been triaged & therefore, not ready for work

issue.body:
### Describe the bug

The reindex user operation cannot be run in production due to users count

### To Reproduce

1. Add more than 1000 users to your database
2. Launch `stud42cli operations reindexusers`

### Expected behavior

_No response_

### Relevant log output

```Shell
11:47PM INF Start the re-indexation of the users version=v0.19
11:47PM INF Start the re-indexation of the users batchCount=27 usersCount=26714 version=v0.19
11:47PM INF Reindexing users in batch batchId=0 usersCount=1000 version=v0.19
11:47PM FTL failed to index user error="MeilisearchCommunicationError unable to execute request (path \"PUT /indexes/s42_users/documents?primaryKey=id\" with method \"UpdateDocuments\"): no free connections available to host" version=v0.19
```


### Version of software

0.19

### Environment

Live (https://s42.app)

### Additional context

_No response_

### Code of Conduct

- [X] I agree to follow this project's Code of Conduct

issue.body:
### What version of Materialize are you using?

v0.32.3

### How did you install Materialize?

Materialize Cloud

### What is the issue?

In the log lines below, `<name>` starts with a number, which points to a `CREATE SINK` that spits out a warning, then crashes envd. Validation here should not crash, and we should not make it to avro parsing before spitting out an error to user about naming requirements.

issue.title: yanks might get ignored when the build is still queued

labels.name: E-easy
labels.description: Effort: Should be easy to implement and would make a good first PR

labels.name: A-builds
labels.description: Area: Building the documentation for a crate

issue.body:
So it's not forgotten I'll write down my findings here. 

When we get a `Yank` change from crates-index-diff, we are running an `UPDATE` statement on the `releases` table. 

We only add the release to that table after the build is finished, so when the release is still in our build-queue, or in progress, the yank wouldn't do anything. 

Since we don't check the number of updated rows for that `UPDATE` statement, this also never lead to an error. 


While we could solve this issue by storing the yank-state in the build-queue too, this could also be solved via solving #1011.

issue.title: persist: investigate adding an idempotency token to compare_and_append
issue.body:
The return type of `WriteHandle::compare_and_append` is `-> Result<Result<Result<(), Upper<T>>, InvalidUsage<T>>, ExternalError>`. Notably, after, initializing a shard in the first place, this is the only method in persist that forwards on an ExternalError for the persist user to deal with. Petros wonders whether we can do anything about this.

First, the reason it's there in the first place. The ExternalError in question represents an _indeterminate_ (also commonly called indefinite) error from persist's interaction with aurora. This class of error means that the operation _may have_ been successful but also _may not have_. There are other external systems involved in a compare_and_append call (notably s3) but persist already indefinitely retries these. It also already retries _determinate_ (also called definite) errors on the aurora call.

The compare_and_append signature is currently what it is because of experience with the edge cases involved from maelstrom testing. Specifically, persist's maelstrom testing models a transactional kv api, but it's a close analog for how SQL txns will work at the Materialize level. A transaction is executed as follows:

- the reads are evaluated at `read_ts`
- the writes are staged into a set of differential KVTD tuples at time `write_ts=read_ts+1`
- this batch of tuples is handed to persist `compare_and_append` with `expected_upper=[write_ts]` and `new_upper=[write_ts+1]`. if another txn has concurrently committed, then the compare_and_append call will fail with an expected upper mismatch, and the loop is run again at the new `read_ts`
- more details available at https://github.com/MaterializeInc/materialize/blob/a8c7d5a0e7c2938ce4008cf05618494a82f7a48a/src/persist-client/examples/maelstrom/txn.rs#L53-L96

If we retryied this indeterminate error, the issue that comes up is if on retry we find out that we have an expected upper mismatch. The question is whether the upper is different because our previous errored attempt _actually succeeded_ or if it's different because we raced with another txn and they won. If we retry the first, we'll double commit the txn, which is a correctness violation.

In the case of a SQL txn that we are evaluating on behalf of a user, we can return forward the indeterminate error to them as a pgwire error code that itself indicates an indeterminate error. This is something that is unavoidable in truly distributed SQL database (e.g CockroachDB) for similar reasons to what's described above.

Sources, on the other hand, have more information and, with care, can avoid either bubbling up the error or panic-ing. This breaks down to roughly two cases:

- timestamp bindings: The compare_and_append on behalf of timestamp bindings is free to retry the ExternalError. If it then hits an expected upper mis-match, it can proceed the same way regardless of whether it's "racing with itself" or actually racing with another timestamp binding process. Reload the state from scratch as if starting for the first time (more likely have a permanent Listen and wait for it to update) and rerun the timestamp binding logic.
- raw reclocked source data: Similar to the above, if a compare_and_append fails, load the new timestamp bindings and rerun the reclocking logic.

Petros's (very much reasonable) request is for persist to internally use an idempotency token to reduce/remove storage's need to reason about this in the first place. The question of whether this is possible at all is clearly yes. However, to me, the real question is where along the spectrum of things we can do is the right place to be.

On one end, we have the current situation of no idempotency token and no internal retries of indeterminate errors on the aurora cas operation.

On the other end, we remove the ExternalError from the signature entirely and figure out how to make that correct for all of sql txns, timestamp bindings, and raw reclocked source data. The trivial way to do this (tho unworkable for obvious reasons) is to generate a unique idempotency token for every write and whenever a write commits to the persist state, it atomically adds its token to an uncompactable list in the state. This would allow persist to always be able to distinguish between the "raced with self" vs "raced with other" case.

But can we do this without the (unworkable) unbounded state? I'm about 90% sure the answer is no for reasons I'll explain below. However, I do feel there's _something_ in this spectrum that we could make work for everyone. I'm just not sure what it is yet and AFAICT, at earliest, we don't need to figure this out until some part of M2. At which point, we'll have more time (ha) and more experience with the subtleties of all this stuff.

Okay, here's why the general problem is hard. Given the following assumptions:
- We must always be correct
- Persist compare_and_append calls must be "cancel safe". (This is the only sort of timeout available in persist and I'm not ready to make this sort of opinionated change without getting more experience running this stuff in prod than we have right now.)
- The standard distributed systems assumptions (networks are fallible, reorderings can happen, etc)

If we aim to get rid of ExternalError entirely, this means each individual compare_and_append call must be able to (a) get an Indeterminate error and then (b) get an upper mismatch on retry and (c) _always_ be able to correctly determine whether that individual write applied or not. At long last, the reasons this is hard (not possible?) with bounded state is the following:

- We can't distinguish between metadata (unique id per write handle, expected_upper, new_upper etc) because it's always possible that a previous write_and_append call with exactly the same metadata got sent off from the same WriteHandle, timed out and returned control to the persist user after sending off the aurora cas call, and then the aurora cas hung out in the network until hitting aurora at just the wrong moment. It matters if it was the earlier call vs this one because they could have different data/updates, which are stored in s3.
- Okay so can we look up the data in s3 and then tell for sure? Not always. While all these retries were happening, it's possible that some ReadHandle advanced the since and then compaction has erased the ability to distinguish updates at the original timestamps.

Here's some unstructured thoughts from the last time I had this loaded up in my head:
- A trivial thing is to give each write a unique idempotency token and store in the persist state the token of the _most recent_ write. A variant of this is to store the token of the _most recent write for each write handle_. These would cover the vast vast majority of cases in practice, but doesn't allow us to remove ExternalError from the signature entirely.
- Add an explicit timeout to compare_and_append (including a new error type in the return) and then say compare_and_append is not cancel safe. Users that know they aren't handing in a timeout could safely panic on it. This is real clunky.
- A possibly workable option is for a timeout (dropped compare_and_set future) to "posion" the current writer_id locally on the WriteHandle. Perhaps by setting a bool or something at the start of the write and unsetting it when the aurora cas is resolved. Then if another compare_and_set comes and the bool is poisoned, it first expires the old writer id (to keep bounded state size), registers a new writer id (which doesn't necessarily need to involve the network), and then proceed as normal. This would maybe allow persist to use some combination of writer_id, write_idempotency_token, new_upper to always be able to distinguish the two cases? It would also have the benefit of "pay for what you use" in that persist users that don't timeout never hit this extra logic. It's not _obviously_ correct to me exactly how this would work and it's also quite a subtle/brittle protocol involving persist state, local write handle state, and some knowledge of orderings, so I'd be pretty anxious about moving to this without some really solid adversarial testing to make sure it doesn't break end-to-end.

issue.title: fix(developer): handle shutdown cleanup more cleanly
issue.body:
Fixes #4757.
Fixes #6928.

This may also fix some other Developer crashes relating to CEF, as some of those are probably due to unclean shutdown.

Three separate ways shutdown is more robust:

1. Destroy main form before web server -- this ensures that all main form routines have deregistered app sources from web server.
2. In some situations, `FormClose` can be skipped by shutdown routines, for example, if you call `Application.Terminate`. This change ensures that we get a second chance to cleanup in the form destructor with `DoCloseCleanup`.
3. In the Online Update Check, instead of `Application.Terminate`, we now use `Application.MainForm.Close`, which is much more polite, as it ensures that changed files are saved, etc, and does proper cleanup. This particular change may make the other two somewhat irrelevant but they are still sensible as they will cover us for other potential form destruction sequences.

@keymanapp-test-bot skip

Note: when the regression test for Keyman Developer is run for Beta, we'll be checking most of these code pathways. Some of these are hard to reproduce in beta testing in any case, so we'll monitor Sentry for other possible crash reports.

issue.title: Festival dashboard - Deleted user breaks analytics buyer tables
issue.body: Bug found thanks to these 2 sentry errors: - [Cannot read properties of null (reading 'orgId')](https://sentry.io/organizations/cascade-8/issues/3741910248/?referrer=slack) - [Cannot destructure property 'uid' of 'object null' as it is null.](https://sentry.io/organizations/cascade-8/issues/3777971795/?referrer=slack) User id `bMlhoO6asTfb68BQX1LixYqtOdz1` It breaks the top 5 active buyers table on dashboard homepage ((/c/o/dashboard/home) ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14964443/204805473-8546d955-1ead-4779-b469-159490472f7b.png) and then all the buyers stats (/c/o/dashboard/home/buyer) Could we exclude data that are pointing to deleted users?
